_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Kelso Milling Co.

1205 Main St.

Scott City, Mo. 63780

Further Information Contact:  Jeff Kirn/Plant Manager (573) 979-1226

Risk Management Plan-Executive Summary



1.  Facility Policy:  The owner & employees of Kelso Milling Co. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to surrounding patrons and the environment.

2.  Facility information:  The primary activity at the facility is blending and storage of fertilizer, and sale of agricultural products. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and filled for direct application by farmers.

The maximum intended inventory stored is 319,190.47  pounds when our East Storage Tank, West Storage Tank, and all of our nurse wagons are full. Our West Stationary tank has a 12,000 gallon water capacity and our East Stationary Tank has a 11,648 water gallon capacity.

3.  The accidental release prevention program.  Kelso Milling Co. has implemented the provisions of "ANSI(American National Standard Inc)/CGA(Compressed Gas Association) G-2.1-2014 REQUIREMENTS FOR THE STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA, and the US Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia."

4.  The five year accident history.  There have been no reportable accidents, or releases with anhydrous ammonia at our facility in the last 5 years. 

Emergency Action 

We are a NON-RESPONDING FACILITY.

     The facility has:

a.  a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38

b.  Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community Right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)

c.  A written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.120 including pre-emergency planning and

employee training.





Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  We have installed new bulk heads at each stationary tank, along with a new liquid pump at our West Stationary Tank and East Stationary tank.  Our nurse wagons have been pressure, visually, and thickness tested up to date.  We recently installed new Safety Tripod Couplers, as well as Pressure Relief Valve Manifolds on our Stationary tanks. New Emergency signage has been added to the facility as well. Concrete barricades have been installed around each of our storage tanks.  Bleed off water storage has been added for safe vapor release of chemical left in hose at time of tanker trailer filling our storage tanks.
